citations.narrative:
Three enclosures had water pipes made of PVC that were loose and hanging down within the enclosures. Loose pipes
hanging within an enclosure could result in injury to the dog. In addition, this could also be enticing for the dogs to chew
on which could lead to ruptured pipes in the future. All pipes must be secured so they aren't dangling around. Correct by
4/12/23.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
Feces was accumulating in the outdoor enclosures. The flooring of the outdoor enclosures was caked in feces. The
licensee just moved the dogs into this sheltered enclosure in February and he hasn't cleaned the outdoor part since he
has moved the dogs into this building. In the indoor part of the shelter, feces is building up underneath the enclosures.
The licensee stated the underneath part hasn't been cleaned in about a month.
Not cleaning the outdoor part of the enclosures on a daily basis and underneath the indoor enclosures as often as
necessary to prevent an excessive accumulation of feces can attract pests and can contribute to the spread of disease.
Excreta and food waste must be removed from the enclosures on a daily basis and must be removed from under the
primary enclosures as often as necessary to prevent an excessive accumulation of feces.
Correct by 4/7/23.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
The outdoor enclosures haven't been sanitized since the licensee has moved the dogs into the new sheltered building
back in February. Not sanitizing the enclosures every two weeks doesn't ensure that the various types of germs (such as
viruses, bacteria, parasites, etc.) have been killed. All enclosures must be sanitized every two weeks or more often as
necessary. Correct by 4/7/23.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
Clutter was observed through the sheltered building. Carpets, empty dog food bags, bleach bottles, medication bottles
were observed underneath empty enclosures and within empty enclosures. In addition, the floors were filthy. The floors
were covered in grime, dog food, and dust.
The clutter makes it more difficult for the building to be properly cleaned. The food, dust, and grime found on the floors
can attract rodents, flies, and other pests.
The clutter needs to be removed from underneath the enclosures and within the empty enclosures. Trash needs to be
thrown out and cleaning supplies and medications should be stored in cabinets or in another spot that doesn't contribute
to cluttering up the facility. The floors need to be swept and cleaned of the food, dust and grime.
Correct by 4/7/23.

At least ten adult dogs were not up to date on their rabies vaccination. In addition none of the dogs have been sampled
for heartworm or fecal parasites. Not having all adult dogs up to date on their rabies shots and not sampling the kennel
for heartworm or fecal parasites doesn't ensure the dogs are adequately protected from rabies, heartworm and various
fecal parasites. All adult dogs must be vaccinated for rabies and must be sampled for parasites in accordance with a plan
from the Attending Veterinarian. Correct by 5/5/23.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
End of report.
n

narrative:
3.1(a) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
Three enclosures had water pipes made of PVC that were loose and hanging down within the enclosures.  Loose pipes 
hanging within an enclosure could result in injury to the dog.  In addition, this could also be enticing for the dogs to chew 
on which could lead to ruptured pipes in the future.  All pipes must be secured so they aren't dangling around.  Correct by 
4/12/23. 
3.11(a) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
Feces was accumulating in the outdoor enclosures.  The flooring of the outdoor enclosures was caked in feces.  The 
licensee just moved the dogs into this sheltered enclosure in February and he hasn't cleaned the outdoor part since he 
has moved the dogs into this building.  In the indoor part of the shelter, feces is building up underneath the enclosures.  
The licensee stated the underneath part hasn't been cleaned in about a month. 
 
Not cleaning the outdoor part of the enclosures on a daily basis and underneath the indoor enclosures as often as 
necessary to prevent an excessive accumulation of feces can attract pests and can contribute to the spread of disease. 
 
Excreta and food waste must be removed from the enclosures on a daily basis and must be removed from under the

primary enclosures as often as necessary to prevent an excessive accumulation of feces. 
 
Correct by 4/7/23. 
3.11(b)(2) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
The outdoor enclosures haven't been sanitized since the licensee has moved the dogs into the new sheltered building 
back in February.  Not sanitizing the enclosures every two weeks doesn't ensure that the various types of germs (such as 
viruses, bacteria, parasites, etc.) have been killed.  All enclosures must be sanitized every two weeks or more often as 
necessary.  Correct by 4/7/23. 
3.11(c) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
Clutter was observed through the sheltered building.  Carpets, empty dog food bags, bleach bottles, medication bottles 
were observed underneath empty enclosures and within empty enclosures.  In addition, the floors were filthy.  The floors 
were covered in grime, dog food, and dust. 
 
The clutter makes it more difficult for the building to be properly cleaned.  The food, dust, and grime found on the floors 
can attract rodents, flies, and other pests. 
 
The clutter needs to be removed from underneath the enclosures and within the empty enclosures.  Trash needs to be 
thrown out and cleaning supplies and medications should be stored in cabinets or in another spot that doesn't contribute 
to cluttering up the facility.  The floors need to be swept and cleaned of the food, dust and grime.

Correct by 4/7/23. 
3.13(a)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
At least ten adult dogs were not up to date on their rabies vaccination.  In addition none of the dogs have been sampled 
for heartworm or fecal parasites.  Not having all adult dogs up to date on their rabies shots and not sampling the kennel 
for heartworm or fecal parasites doesn't ensure the dogs are adequately protected from rabies, heartworm and various 
fecal parasites. All adult dogs must be vaccinated for rabies and must be sampled for parasites in accordance with a plan 
from the Attending Veterinarian.  Correct by 5/5/23. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee. 
 
End of report.
